title: Eken H9R Action Camera Lens Hood

description.text:
Here is the lens hood to cover side light (there are two pictures to show the effect)
Eken H9R has 20.8mm diameter lens, so the unit has 21m hole. You might zoom with your slicer to adjust the hole size for your meeds. The hood is for the 170 degree lens angle.

Obviously it is recommended to use black (mate) filament to avoid reflections.

The printing face down, no additional support needed. Even with this low angle using 0.1mm layer high and good cooling the PLA 50mm/s, 0.4mm nozzle seems to print nice.

author: mariomsyano

description.text:
This may help if you need a long strip of GT2 timing belt.  Please note that it is open on both ends and it's not a closed belt.  This is useful for linear motion control projects such as 3D printers.  When unspooled, the belt length is a little over 36".  
This will obviously not work as a belt when printed with ABS or PLA (duh!).  You'll need NinjaFlex or similar flexible material.  Please note that NinjaFlex does stretch a little!  Commercial quality timing belts usually bend but not stretch like rubber bands.  Stretching can cause issues when the load offers resistance.  Although I haven't tried it, it may be good enough for 3D printers and other light use.
Print with flexible material such as NinjaFlex.

description.text:
Edit: The better thing for two mosfets is this thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2474585 Unfortunately my version for two mosfets blocks the USB-port.

Quick'n'dirty mosfet mount für the Anet A6 for one and two of the more uncommon mosfets (210A, 12V-50V, 70x45mm).

Features:
-Mosfet boards mount securely with screws
-Does not block top hole
-Does not block micro-sd slot
-Minimal size
-unfortunately he dual version doesn't fully fit in the A6 frame (the upper mosfet is wider than the frame, as you can see in the pic)
-you only need the remaining screws and nuts of the A6 DIY Kit

Holes are sized for M3 screws. In my printouted version (on my stock A6) the M3 screws are fixed without nuts, but there are holes for nuts if your printer is more accurate.

author: mariomsyano

description.text:
Looking for someone with metal working/milling abilities to realize this<<

Seeing several attempts to create extruders with two drive gears, I tried to replicate that. By adding a 2nd axis with a 2nd drive gear which gets driven by the extruder motor over two simple herringbone gears one should get more control over the filament.
The tension is produced by 4 m3 screws with springs on it.
I imagine by replacing the normal guide bearing with and actively driven gear, there will be more motor power transmitted onto the filament. The hole are designed for small bearing 10mm OD and 5mm ID.
This could be especially interesting for 3mm bowden set ups, because if the driving force only comes from one side the possibility of biting pieces out of the filament is high. The 2nd gear could distribute more force more evenly.

The drive gears have a m5 bore, so a m5 screw should do.
The screw need to have some dents dremeled in for the set screws to hold.
In a future version I will allow space for ball bearings which would hold the 2nd axis, it will probably work is a smooth rod screw as well.
The cogwheel has a flat hole in it in the form of a motor shaft, it still needs to be tested if that gives it enough grip to effectively drive the 2nd drive gear.
V7 is just to illustrate how the parts go together, the newer versions improved.

comments.text: Sometimes one dong just won't get the job done. :-)

author: Fuintur

description.text:
Watch here: https://youtu.be/arsoU_mK5vU

This model will be going to Andy from Futurama Shopuk (https://twitter.com/Futurama_shopuk). We've been talking back and forth for quite a bit and we decided on Crushinator. Big thanks to Andy for all the help and feedback.

I created this model in Fusion 360. I used sketches to get the main body shape there. Then I just went through, extruded the details out and adjusted the shapes until everything look correct.

After splitting up the pieces to make them print easier, I used Simplify3D to slice them, then printed them out on my Creality CR-10 3D printer using Hatchbox PLA.

Then my wife sanded and primed it. She used her airbrush to paint the pink colors on, then used paintbrushes and acrylic paints to paint everything else. Then we just super glued it together.

Printer: Creality CR-10
Filament: Hatchbox PLA
Layer Height: 0.1mm
Supports: Yes

description.text:
The general purpose of these designs are described in “3D Printed UV-vis Cuvette Adapter for Low Cost and Versatile Spectroscopic Experiments”, which is published in the open access journal ACS Omega. Link to publication: http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acsomega.7b01310

This particular part is meant to mimic traditional quartz and glass UV-vis Spectrometer cuvettes. In this design, we have a path length of 10 mm and a sample volume of approximately 2.4 mL. The design differs fro the "standard" design only in the label on the side.This cuvette can be used in most standard UV-Vis spectrometers. We recommend printing this design with a black filament to reduce the amount of light scattering.

An instructional video to assemble the spectrometer is shown below (post-printing) with the materials used listed. Either quartz or glass windows can be used depending on the spectral range needed of the cuvette.

title: Shelves with box, wireless charger hold and mobile stand for Dodge RAM 2012-2014

description.text:
I wanted to have a better overview of the things I place in that big space in the middle and I needed a stand for my mobile and didn't want to plugin the cable each time. So I designed this. The inside of a chloetech wireless charger (https://www.amazon.de/dp/B0156OD7JA/ref=twister_B01LYXS8MZ?_encoding=UTF8&psc=1) can be placed in the stand to have the mobile charged wireless.
You should deactivade the screen rotation on the phone otherwise when you hit the breakes a little hard...

Under the phone stand there are two hidden spaces (one below the other) for whatever nobody shall see. If you don't want the phone charger & stand, there is a lid to be printed instead.
Have fun with it.

author: mandarim

title: Anycubic Delta Trigorilla low mount and fan support

description.text:
UPDATE 2017/07/31: WARNING: I realized than 20mm fans are very hard to find, and the standard is 25mm. Please use thinner fans to avoid being too close to the printing bed.

NEW 2x40mm fan support hold in place without hardware.

This is an experimental design for the Trigorilla board mount on the Anycubic Delta Mini (240mm profiles).

The idea behind is to have powerful cooling by placing a 92mm fan over the board that it's easily removable. The fan support is attached to the screw boards through 4 magnets.

By using a 20mm thick fan, the remaining space between the glass bed and the fan is 10mm +/- that can be increased using thinner fans.

The USB and power cord wires will NOT be accessible from the outside of the printer, in my opinion, this is not a big problem but you can always make an extension cable.

Structure assembly:
4xM4 square nut or t-nut
4xM4 8mm screws

Trigorilla board assembly:
4xM3 nut
4xM3 8mm screws + shim

Fan assembly:
4xM4 nut
4xM4 25mm screws
4x 5mm diameter magnets

Instructions:

Insert the M3 nuts in the Trigorilla mount and screw the board to it without tightening it.
Then install the whole assembly in the lower profiles of the structure and screw it to it with the m4 square nuts (or t-nuts). When everything is in place and perfectly squared, tight all the screws.
Now install your 92mm fan to the fan support by inserting the M4 nuts in place and screwing to them. The magnets have to be glued to the columns of the fan support, the best way to do that is to put the magnets on the Trigorilla screws and add a bit of glue to them, then just press the fan support against them in order to place the magnets at the right distance inside the columns.

remixed_from.title: ANET A8 Smart Fixator and Tensioner for X-Belt

title: ANET A8 X-Belt Fixer-Tensioner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This device replaces the two bolts/cable ties mechanism for fixing the ANET A8 x-belt to the extruder carriage. It allows very quick tension adjustments without the need for complicated tensioning mechanisms.

This is a ground-up remake of the part designed by BoldBadger that I built in TinkerCAD.

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2351679

I loved the simplicity of BoldBadger's design, but the inwardly repositioned gripper mounts made it impossible for me to fit without buying a longer belt (I obviously cut mine too short). My take on the design is to move the gripper mounts outwards, back in line with the original bolts so you can use your existing belt.

There are two versions: The first version was based on BoldBadger's dimensions, which needs a M3 x 12mm bolt; the second uses the existing M3 x 18mm without the need for nuts as spacers.

The grippers are really tight, but the belt will fit. Try feeding one tooth. Push the belt right into the groove. I used a 6" metal ruler which is ideal.

This design overhangs the edges of the extruder carriage by 2mm either side. This does not affect it any way, but looks unfinished to me. I will probably provide a flush version later if it is a big issue.

Printer:

ANET A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

comments.text: Just printed this and fixed it in no time. The original belt went in without a problem and is very easy to tension. Thanks for taking the trouble to modify and post this. Its excellent
comments.author: Steverh

comments.text: So. I printed this so I can try to tighten my belt better than the stock way with the screws and zip ties until my GT2 belts get here. How do you get the belt pulled tight and then threaded into the toothed area? The original design states "Correcting the tension is finished after 20 seconds, power off not needed." What does that mean? It only lasts for 20 seconds?
comments.author: kremit

comments.text:
It's very straightforward. I would recommend powering the printer off. I don't have a video, but I found than angling the belt at the bottom of the first tooth and sliding in one tooth at a time opened the gap enough for all to slide in. Try this a few times when loose to see how it's done. I tensioned by simply pulling the belt tight with my fingers and following the one-tooth-at-a-time method again. If you struggle to get the tension you could always grip and pull with pliers, which I've also tried
. Once all teeth are all meshed and the belt is aligned I pushed it right into the slot with a 6" steel rule, also with a flat blade cutlery knife and a small screwdriver. Just give it a try.
comments.author: kremit

comments.text: How am I supposed to put the belt in the print? It's very very hard to do so. Let alone put in it with a tight fit instead of a loose one. Any video tutorials on this?
comments.author: _MsG_

comments.text: No video tutorials I'm afraid. It didn't need one. It is a tight fit, but I found that by starting on the first tooth at the bottom, angle the belt at 45 degrees, it slid into that one tooth and provides enough displacement to allow the rest of the belt to slide in. After looping around the gripper, I then used a thin 6" steel engineers ruler to slide the belt the whole way into the groove to give perfect belt alignment.
comments.author: _MsG_

comments.author: heidebill

comments.text:
Thanks for the time put into getting the measurements right, the holes line up perfectly.
I modded the mesh putting a little tab on the front and back so that the battery can't slide forward and back, put some rubber weather stripping tape down and with one velcro strap, it doesn't move at all. However, with two phantom stock batteries 2200m 3S hooked up in parallel, a brushless gimbal with a GoPro3+ I only get about 7.5 minutes fly time. With a single battery and the gimbal+GoPro, I get 4.5 minutes. Seems like I should be getting around 10 for two batteries. I wonder if it's because where these sit, it is directly in the prop wash zone, so the motors are having to work harder to keep it afloat. Also, keep in mind that this was tested inside a big shop, no GPS and running in ATT mode, just flying around the room.
I may just design one that stacks two batteries behind the gimbal mount directly under the belly. See if I get better battery life that way.

print_settings.Notes:: I recommend that this be printed at the fastest speed your printer will allow. The cheap filament I was using didn't bond together at anything over 60mm/sec, so I was only able to print three to four panels a day.

title: FIFO Rolling Can Pantry Organizer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
So, this is, to date, my largest and most complicated design/print yet! If you are like me and have cabinets full of canned goods - always be prepared! - you know what a hassle it is to keep those rotated so that the oldest cans can be taken first. This solves that problem. Simply drop your can into the opening on top and it will roll down to the bottom. As you take a can from the bottom opening, the next can in line will roll down to take it's place. By filling the rack from the top and taking from the bottom, you ensure that the oldest can is always pulled first.

There are two versions included here. The build plate on my Tevo Tarantula is the standard 200x200 so I had to cut the model into pieces to make it fit. For those with larger beds, or those having this printed, I have also included the original model with full size panels as a ZIP file. You can ignore this if you will be printing this piece by piece.

A word of warning, this does take a LOT of filament. My print utilized 351.55m and 1004g - right at, or just over, a typical 1kg roll. Use the cheapest filament you can. Looks are not important here. You can always sand it and paint it after assembly if you want.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

Most of these pieces print best when the text is face down, with supports, if your bed is large enough - keep reading for more details. The four shelf panels need to be laid flat against the bed. Cura has a button under [Rotate] that does that automatically, otherwise the angle is 5°.

As I said, my build plate is the original 200x200mm. These panels do NOT fit on a bed that size laying flat. I know, but there was nothing I could do about that. The first panel I printed, I printed standing on edge diagonally across the bed. For this you will need supports enabled everywhere. This printed good - maybe even with more strength - but there is a lot of cleanup.

For the rest of the panels, I cheated. I cut a piece of glass 200x 250 and placed that on the heat bed with the edge hanging over slightly at the front. I then moved the Y-axis end stop back so that the printer could home to the left front corner. I also had to tell Cura and OctoPrint that I was using a larger bed and I had to modify the maximum XY size in the Marlin firmware. It works, though! I did let the bed heat up for an addition 10 minutes or so so that the heat could migrate to the unsupported glass, but not a single print failed.

I recommend that this be printed at the fastest speed your printer will allow. The cheap filament I was using didn't bond together at anything over 60mm/sec, so I was only able to print three to four panels a day.

This is designed to fit together like a jigsaw puzzle. You will notice that each panel is labeled as to it's position as well as to which tabs go together. If you can put together IKEA furniture, then you can assemble this. I used Duco cement on some panels and E6000 cement on others. Either seems to hold together just fine, but I would probably suggest the E6000 for this application since the longer cure time seems to indicate a stronger bond. Assembly is easier if the rear panel is attached last.

A friend commented on how plain the front was. We decided that the upper front panel is a great place to paste the label of the cans stored in each rack.

This was designed in my go-to CAD program - Sketchup. Contrary to popular opinion, this is a GREAT program that is easy to use and creates perfectly 3D printable models if you know what you are doing. Like any program, there is a learning curve, but it's nothing like that of Blender or FreeCAD!

I tried to cut a slew of 20mm diameter holes in the sides to cut down on the amount of filament necessary, but that didn't result in a significant drop in filament use. The reason, I think, is this... As designed, 99% of the panel is 10% infill with only the outer edges needing full fill. Now when I cut holes, yes the total surface area is reduced, but the edges around each hole now need full fill. This adds almost as much filament as the holes themselves remove.

If you can figure out a way to reduce the amount of filament needed, I would LOVE to see it.

description.text:
The general purpose of these designs are described in “3D Printed UV-vis Cuvette Adapter for Low Cost and Versatile Spectroscopic Experiments”, which is published in the open access journal ACS Omega. Link to publication: http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acsomega.7b01310

This particular part is meant to allow reproducible analysis of films on a microscope slide held at an angle of 22.5 degrees relative to the light of the spectrometer. This adapter can be used in most standard UV-Vis spectrometers. We recommend printing this design with a black filament to reduce the amount of light scattering.

title: 12 mm laser mount for atlas 3d scanner

description.text:
This is a quick and dirty 12mm laser mount for the atlas 3d scanner. (For the printed version of the scanner. Will not fit the acrylic enclosure) May be usable in other applications as well. Includes the .stl file and the rsdoc file that can be edited in Design Spark Mechanical. mix to your heart's content. Use this mount for left or right side.

Note** Will require some reduction (grinding to remove where it is too long for hole to line up.) on the rounded side where the hole is for mount to the arm. It's about 1/8 to 3/16 too long past the hole. Either edit in design spark and re-share or grind it off a little on a bench grinder or something. I don't care to re-edit it personally because mine fit now after grinding a little off.

The distance from the center of the laser to the mount hole for the arm is correct though and I get good scans with it.

description.text:
The general purpose of these designs are described in “3D Printed UV-vis Cuvette Adapter for Low Cost and Versatile Spectroscopic Experiments”, which is published in the open access journal ACS Omega. Link to publication: http://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acsomega.7b01310

This particular part is meant to mimic traditional quartz and glass UV-Vis Spectrometer cuvettes. In this design, we have a path length of 7 mm. This cuvette can be used in most standard UV-vis spectrometers. We recommend printing this design with a black filament to reduce the amount of light scattering.

An instructional video to assemble the spectrometer is shown below (post-printing) with the materials used listed. Either quartz or glass windows can be used depending on the spectral range needed of the cuvette.

title: GlueDart. Glue pen with motor extruder case.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Today, glue guns are widely used in everyday life and in production. They are used by makers and builders, home masters and professionals. Makers of the whole world use glue guns for gluing various surfaces (textiles, paper, plastic, wood, etc.). The glue gun is indispensable in many types of creativity and needlework (quilling, scrapbooking, floristry, decoration, etc.).
I often use the glue gun in my work. And I have wanted to have a glue gun, which will produce a drop of glue and dosage will be easier to use, such as 3d pen.
I created a model of a glue pen with an electric extruder. I took the heater out of the ordinary glue gun. The body and all the mechanical parts are created in Fusion 360. After that, I printed all the details on the 3d printer.

https://youtu.be/r6u5CyPdeLA

GlueDart works with 11 mm glue rods
I want to create a glue pen for 7 mm rods and 12-volt power.

You can see the full instructions on https://www.instructables.com/id/GlueDart-Glue-Pen-With-Electric-Motor-Extruder/

title: Master Sword Pedestal of Time (for digital calipers)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My digital calipers would always be too tall for my pen holder so I decided to design a dedicated stand for them. I modeled this stand after a pedestal that holds the Master Sword from The Legend of Zelda series.

It fits the Harbor Freight "Pittsburgh" digital calipers and I'm sure it will fit most other similar ones.

I printed it in black PLA and gave it it a paint job using grey filler primer and a few spritzes of flat black to give it a stone effect. Then I added some detailing creating cracks and notches with a knife and darkened the Triforce with a fine Sharpie marker.

If I had to do it again, I would have sanded all surfaces with 120 grit sandpaper to smooth out the layer lines that show through the filler primer.

Feel free to remix this to fit different sized calipers, scissors, pens, markers, whatever. Enjoy!

UPDATE 9/18/2017: Corrected orientation of ST file with bottom side down.

title: Taranis QX7 Boom Box Mod
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted more bass from my background music, and liked the 36mm speaker mod for the x9 but of course the Qx7 has almost no space between the stock speaker mount and the transmitter board, so I needed a new place for my speaker upgrade.
My unused module bay was the obvious answer!
So I took the great fitting module bay cover and 36mm speaker mod pulled them together in tinkercad here so you all can customize it however you like and printed it out.
It's a perfect fit!
Like so good, I was going to epoxy the speaker in, but it is being pressed just the right amount down by the cover that no glue is needed! No rattles at all! (of course you can still glue the speaker in if you want.)

Speaker I used from amazon (~$12 for 4 speakers) http://a.co/05NVfww

Anet A2

author: danielstinebaugh

description.text:
Oberwagenlaterne der Deutschen Reichsbahn (DDR) im Maßstab 1:11 für Modelle auf 5'' Spur. Maße: B 22 x T 20 x H 48 mm

Der Deckelhalter wird mit dem Deckel verklebt und kann dann auf den Korpus geclipst werden. Der Fuss wird an den Korpus geklebt und passt in die Knupfer-Signalhalter.

Der Korpus ist so konstruiert, dass in die Lampenfassung die oberen 5,0 mm einer E5,5 Schraubfassung für Miniaturbirnchen geklipst werden kann an die ein Kabel gelötet ist, vorher wird in die Vertiefung eine Mutter M1,6 gelegt an der die andere Ader angelötet ist. Das zweiadrige Kabel kann dann durch eines der Löcher nach außen geführt werden. An den Stirnseiten ist ein Schlitz für eine klare oder rote Kunststofffolie als Scheibe und das Reflektorelement wird zweifach ausgedruckt und passt genau in den Zwischenraum.

Der Bügel ist aus 0,8 mm starkem Messingdraht gebogen. Ein weiterer Messingdraht passt als Splint in den Fuß und verhindert Verlust.

Gedruckt mit 0,25 mm Düse und 0,1 mm Layer height in ABS. Beim Korpus wird Support benötigt damit die Brücke über der Öffnung halbwegs sauber gedruckt wird. Die Druckteile wurden danach abgeschliffen und mit Acteon dampfbehandelt.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,1 mm / 0,25 mm Nozzle

After 4x prototypes, I've finally got a perfect model. All you need is

2x M6 Lock Nuts
2x M3 Lock Nuts
2x M3x20 Capscrews
Superglue

Print all the parts and then glue them together. The Gel Superglue works a bit better. It is light weight, very strong and you will be much more visible on the road.

Numberplate size is 170mm x 120mm

No modification is necessary on the bike. Just remove the stock flickers and remove the rubber spacer and mount on the new bracket using the same screw and a spacer washer included in the files.

Printer:

UM2 Clone

No

50%

author: fcanestro

description.text: This is a spool holder for my large format Delta (Kossel). To help with scale this machine pictured is capable of 20" diameter X 36" tall prints. Depending on the length of the cross beam at the top you could space this for multiple spools. I have my spaced for up to 3 at a time. The design includes grips to hold on to the end of the filament for you so you don't have to find it. The receivers on each end are sized for 1/2" bar stock. I put bearings on mine and printed a tubular sleeve to be just under the I.D. of the spools I use. I printed this with PLA.

Trimble SketchUP design

I have included the SKU file for you if you want to make modifications. Google SketchUP has a free version that works quite well and should be able to read and modify this file as you see fit.

This is the Sphinx rep-tile, four units of which create a larger version of the same tile. The sphinx is the best-known pentagonal rep-tile.

The scale, width of the outline, the extruded height and form are customisable

print_settings.Notes:: print the tabs long end flat.  at a 45 degree angle, you should not need supports.

author: ikishk

description.text:
This is an abstract shape made using OpenScad's scripting abilities. I watched an episode of Maker's Muse (hi!) that talked about an older open source project for generating procedural shapes. It seemed like I could make the same kinds of things pretty quickly using OpenScad, so I gave it a try. This is one of the results. The .scad file is included for those who want to tinker with it. The code for something like this is short, and can be made shorter with some attention to technique ;).

Note: this is pretty challenging to print using FFF. Most intermediate enthusiasts can get a better print than I can, but I am still working on my support-making and bridging skills, and trying to dial in my printer (a FolgerTech i3 2020). You can see from the photos that I still have some surface problems, and my over-the-top supports did not separate as well as I had hoped. Lesson learned: supports will fuse to each other even though they are configured to separate from the print, apparently. Have a chisel handy, or do a better job than I did at support generation ;)

See post-print video for a better view of the final print.

title: Hearthstone Class Tokens for Fireside Gatherings and Tournaments

description.text:
Hearthstone class tokens! These are super useful for picking bans during tournaments; grab a set of tokens representing the classes you are playing, and then trade with your opponent. Secretly pick one coin as a ban, and then reveal them at the same time. Easy pie!

(They also make great, cheap swag)

These should print fine on most .4mm nozzle printers or smaller.

If surface details aren't "popping", you can scale the Z-axis height and increase the thickness (currently at 2mm).

Each coin weighs less than two grams, so it should only cost two to five cents per token in raw materials.

You can either color code the classes when you print them:

Rogue- Black
Warrior- Red
Mage- Light/clear blue
Druid- Brown
Hunter- Green
Shaman- Dark Blue
Priest- White
Paladin- Yellow
Warlock- Purple

...Or print them all in a neutral color that is fairly contrasty (like silver, or grey).

Enamel paint can also be used, but I haven't played around with that.

Ideally you should have at least two tokens of each class, but if you print enough for everyone (i.e. 16 tokens for each class for a 16 person tournament), players can carry their tokens around with them).

description.text:
/update 21 aug 2017
I redesigned the case + mount. The improvements

  • Lid fits more firm within the case
  • Flat cable is at the bottom, no need to flip the camera in Octoprint
  • Designed a mount as well, case fits firmly on the ball

I first printed this Camera mount https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2333969, then I needed the Camera case, I printed this one https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1646474 to only discover that my camera didn't fit. I have a clone version (https://www.banggood.com/Camera-Module-For-Raspberry-Pi-3-Model-B-2B-B-A-p-1051437.htm) which is different. So I went and printed this one http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1936349, looked kind of the same, but unfortunately didn't fit.

A while back I followed a few fusion 360 courses on Udemy, so this is my first real project designing something. Printed version 1, made a few small changes and printed it again and I am pretty satisfied with the result.

As I already printed a lot from thingiverse, its time to give back. I also included the fusion 360 file if someone wants to improve on my design.

description.text:
I wanted a dock that could hold both my Apple Watch and Apple AirPods. I found lots of designs that were one or the other, or AirPods and iPhone, but not Watch and AirPods.

So I took inspiration from 2 other things to create my own.

Designed from scratch using Fusion 360. Integrated cable management for both your Apple watch and AirPods charger. After my initial design I revised this one with a hole in the back of the watch charger indent to push something through to help with removing the cable from the dock should you ever need to replace it.

Let me know if it works for you!

title: Four Corners Tak Board
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This design allows the board to be printed in Four Corners (pun intended). Print 3 pieces of "3Corners" and 1 of "4thCorner"

My first reason for this design was that it should fit on an MP Select Mini, but it occurs to me it would also be somewhat more portable this way. I may design a version which allows the pieces to interlock and be used as storage cases. Designed in 123D (file included)

Update 2017/07/28: Fixed some issues and added a chamfer to the edge of the board, updated the STLs and 123D file.

Update 2017/08/15: Added a 6x6/7x7 board! Also added fairly basic 30 piece sets with cap stones.

Update 2017/08/15 PART 2!!: Added 6x6/7x7 board with joints as well as a "joint test" so you can dial in your print settings to make the joint work. You'll probably need to use supports to get the female side of the joint to print properly.

Printer:

MP Mini Select v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.2625

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Make sure your solid top layers are better than 1mm for best results. This will ensure the lines between spaces will be printed cleanly.

If printing the "joint" version, you may want to print the "joint test" first to make sure your settings will work properly. Supports are suggested for this version.

title: TrackIR mount (for Oculus rift sensor)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I needed a new mount for my TrackIR camera for two reasons. First the original flimsy monitor mount sucks and was broken. Secondly, I needed the sensor further away then my monitor and the Oculus Rift sensor was already at the perfect distance, so why not combine them? :)

There are four variants of holders, two is for the camera straight forward and the other at a 5 degree angle. My IR-leds are mounted to the left of my headset so I prefer to have the camera slightly angled to the left. Variants "A" for mounting above and variants "B" for mounting below.

I designed this to be mounted with M5 screw, washer and nut.

title: Rain Gauge Spider and Wasp Repeller

description.text:
I have an AcuRite wireless rain gauge (less than $25 on Amazon) that works very nicely, but unfortunately is an extremely attractive home for spiders and mud dauber wasps, which build webs and/or hives that restrict the movement of the tipping bucket. Over the years I have found that moth balls or urinal cakes work nicely to repel various pests and decided to try them in this situation as well, but needed some way to hold the mothballs without interfering with the tipping bucket and limit the diffusion rate. I designed the small bucket to fit over the antenna post and added drain holes in case rain splashes in and to allow air circulation. The snap fit cover has vent holes with a drain system to limit water intrusion but allow the vapors to escape. The moth balls will vaporize over time and will need to be replaced every few months.

UPDATE 2-28-18

After about 8 months I needed to replace the batteries and was pleased to find no signs of insect nesting and about 25% of the mothballs were still in the container. This idea has really solved the problem.

I printed these parts using CraftWare medium auto slice without support or raft.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
This is a two piece "brace" for the BF3 FC and the Armattan Chameleon.

I don't much care to run the lipo lead up through the GP mount, nor did I like it just hanging off the side of the frame. Since the BF3 FC is a PDB, I couldn't easily use Armattan's provided XT60 saver so I, with some help, came up with this design.

I've printed it in PLA+ and TPU. While PLA+ worked, 5-6 hard crashes and it broke up a bit. The TPU version is going strong though without any ill effect.

The tabs are there to "lock" the part together, however I found if one makes the lipo lead cables JUST the right size, then the wire will keep the part together perfectly. Otherwise drop a bit of glue/CA on the tabs and press fit.

Note: Due to the frame size the vertical room below the plate is minimal. You will note the top perimeter is very thin. I may do a second revision that lowers the entrance for the Lipo when not using a 4in1 ESC in the stack.

Please let us know if you have success with this part or have any ideas to improve it!

Enjoy!

title: Flyingbear P902 E3D Titan Aero X Carriage

description.text:
This is a X-carriage for the E3D Tian Aero direct drive extruder/hotend combo. The carriage is designed for the Flyingbear P902 but should work just as well for similar printers with a 70mm span between the x-axis smooth rods.

Note: The belt tensioner is inluded for convenience but was not designed by me. The original design is here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2018900

Features

  • Easy mount and removal. One screw and snap-on/snap-off.
  • Low profile (adds to build height)
  • Dual layer fan support
  • Tie wrap pegs

Printing recommendations

I recommend printing the main carriage and belt clip in PETG or similar. PLA will get mushy if the extruder motor gets warm. The other parts can be printed in PLA if you like.

Assembly

  • Take the stock x-assembly apart. Remove the the linear bearings.
  • Put the linear bearings on the smooth rods and re-asseble.
  • Use a little thread lock fluid on the mounting screws
  • Mount the motor and back plate into the carriage
  • Remove the hot end and throat from the heatsink
  • Wiggle the heatsink and guts into place and and screw it tight (use thread lock)
  • Screw the heatsink fan into place. Replace the bottom screw with a longer one that extends through the mounting hole.
  • Screw the hotend and throat into the heatsink from the under side.
  • Mount the radial fan, funnel and cover
  • Optional: add a 30mm fan to the bottom on the opposite side (under carriage). See picture.
  • Optional (recommended): take the heatsink and fan from the stock extruder and mount it on the back of the E3D pancake stepper to keep it cool. Before I did this, I had issues with a warming stepper resulting in loss of torque.
  • Mount the x-carriage tensioner
  • Cut the x-belt to a suitable length so that, after inserting both ends into the clip, there is a little slack that can be tightened with the tensioner.
  • Snap the carriage on place over the linear bearings.
  • Secure the carriage to the bearings with tie-wraps
  • Screw the belt clip to the carriage

Before you start

  • Manually check that the x, y and z end stop line up with the new carriage. You may have to bend the levers.
  • If you add the heatsink and fan to the back you will have to move the z axis endstop to the other smooth rod for lack of space.

Printer:

Flyingbear P902

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 layer, 0.4 nozzle

Infill:

at least 50%

Notes:

The design includes a bl-touch mount but I haven't tried it out so it is probably not the right height. If anyone prints it and tries it, please let me know in the comments if it should go up or down and by how much!

description.text:
This is a replacement cuvette holder for a ThermoFisher Scientific Evolution 201 UV-Visible Spectrophotometer. It may work for similar / related models.

The original equipment configuration used a standard 3.5ml cuvette. (Approx. 12mm x 12mm x 45mm)

Our faculty wanted to try larger sample sizes, which required larger cuvettes.

These cuvette holders replace the original, and attach to the original base plate using the same screw, and holds a 20mm (7ml) or 100mm (35ml) cuvette.

These are shorter than the OEM cuvette holder, allowing the larger cuvettes to extend above the top of the holder, making them easier to grip by hand or tool as needed.

They were printed with 3 shells and a 30% infill to provide some structural strength, as they may be handled by students.

Note: The "20mm" and "100mm" refers to the length of the light path provided by the cuvette.

They were printed in black PLA, to avoid any problems due to the light that could be reflected by other colors.

Printed in black PLA

Inspired by Fidget Spinners I created a toy for our cats.
The boxes can be filled with food and the cat has to rotate the axis to get the food.
The food is ejected by the centrifugal force at one side of the box.

You need to print:
1x base
1x axis
2x box
2x cap

Additionally you need a 608 ball bearing (22mm OD/ 8mm ID).
That are those ball bearings used for the currently famous fidget spinners or for in-line skates.

There are two versions of the base. Chose the one you like.
You have to insert the ball bearing at the top of the base and then to attach the axis.

There are as well two versions of the box that snap in at the end of the axis.
One is with a 10mm opening, one with a 15mm opening.
You can chose that one that fits best the food-size.
Nevertheless the amount of ejected food can be adjusted by rotating the box in the snap-in.

The cap is the same for all boxes and will be screwed together to the box.
For training the cat you may leave them away so the cat can see that there is food inside the box.
(the base was stable enough when our cat tried to get the food from the top of the box ;-) )

Additionally the snap-ins of the axis has a few holes.
These are intended to tie some additional cat toys, e.g. a feather.
This may motivate the cat to play/rotate the toy.

You may check that the slicer does not resize the model when you open it (I assume that the printer is callibrated already)

The railings are printed in four parts: Base, top rail, posts and the decorative centre part.
The centre part comes in a choice of four different patterns and slots into grooves in the base and top rail. (Note: the bottom edge of the centre part is identifiable by the cut-away corners designed to fit neatly around the base of the posts.)
The posts are octagonal in section, and as the base and top rails fit around three sides of each post, the railings can be joined together in a straight line or at angles of 90° or 45°.
All parts need to be fixed permanently into position with a few drops of superglue.
The railings are 3.8cm. high, and the posts are 5cm. high.

PRINTING:
On my 5th Generation Makerbot all parts were printed at the default setting of:
Layer height - .20mm, Infill - 10%, with raft.
Printing times were:
Base - 16min.
Top - 7 min.
Post (print upright) - 23min.
Centre parts varied between 24min. and 30min.

author: Gaudges113

description.text:
A flying saucer. 1950s B movie style.

Simple vector cutting from 3mm MDF, about 150mm / 6 inch across finished. All the parts are small so will fit any laser cutter. Whole thing fits onto a 18"×9" board. Assembly is a bit tight, so be gentle with it.

The tricky bit is to put the three 'walls' with the legs on in first, push them to the centre, and then slip their outer ends into the central ring - without breaking the ring. If you want, change the design and make the slots a bit wider to make this easier, and use more glue afterwards.

This was designed in CorelDraw, but there's a PDF version too. One page has the original design sketch, so you could use that as a start for any redesigns.

I'd love to see someone add some engraved detail onto the walls to give it more flying saucer innards.

print_settings.Notes:: Printed with supports to help with the quality of overhangs.

title: Repeating Crossbow - Modified for 36mm Finishing Nails

description.text:
I modified the body of the crossbow so that it is able to shoot 36mm finishing nails. I also added a handle to the main body, and increased the thickness of the crossbow arms. I also added a window so you can see how many shots are left.

The nails that it shoots are quite specific. They are ~36mm in length, with a shaft width of 1.6mm and a head width of 2.4mm.

You will need the rest of the files from the original crossbow; the arms and the pins. I suggest using M3x12mm bolts instead of the pins.

This thing hurts if it hits you; don't shoot it at a living thing.

title: XYZ DaVinci 1.0 Bowden Carriage Fan Mount 50mm

description.text: This is a custom made layer cooling fan mount and duct specifically made for this bowden carriage but it's original model should work with it too (untested). It is designed to basically just clip on to the carriage from the rear end. This model supports a 50mm fan you can get off amazon for pretty cheap. Note that you may need to extend the Y endstop (literally just attach some cardstock or plastic thin enought to fit in the optical endstop to the Y carriage endstop flag) a little if your fan hits the rear Y-axis rotating rod when homing. You may have to adjust the hotend height in the carriage to get the best airflow if using the first carriage. Fusion 3D file provided. One more thing, you may need to add custom starting gcode to your prints to move the extruder about 80mm out of home Y position to ensure the fan doesn't clip anything on its way to start a print. If you have any questions about how to do anything above, just comment or pm me. With this fan mount, I am now fully set with a bowden DaVinci 1.0 (Wades Extruder, E3D v6, the carriage and fan mount)! NOTE: Only tested on the v1 of the first carriage, but should work on the v2 as well.

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci 1.0 w/E3D v6 + Bowden

description.text: This is a modified version of the original cover by s3rkan that allows space for a battery and necessary circuitry to operate the oscilloscope from a rechargeable Li-ion battery.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2
Cover, printed and assembled. All parts seperate.

I basically took the already created cover by s3rkan and imported the STL file into SketchUp 2016 (Free version). I then proceeded to enlarge the cover to accomodate a 3.7V Li-ion battery (I had lying around), a USB-to-3.7V charger board (with low voltage cutoff protection specifically meant to charge Li-ion batteries), a 3.7V-to-5V Buck boost convertor board (similar to a Minty Boost device) and a On/Off switch.
The USB-to-3.7V board is used to charge the Li-ion battery which is connected to the 3.7V-to-5V booster board via the On/Off switch. The output from the 5V Booster board was soldered onto the 5V supply rail of the oscilloscope near the oscilloscope's USB port. This enables the unit to be completely mobile but still maintaining it's original ability to connect to the computer software via it's USB port. Please note that connecting the unit to the computer through it's original USB port (to be able to run the oscilloscope software) will NOT charge the internal battery. Only by connecting an USB cable to the Li-ion charge board USB port will the battery be charged.
After adding the text logos, I asked a friend to print it for me. I am including the SketchUp file for easy editing to your needs. Kind regards.

remixed_from.author: rrhb
remixed_from.title: Eggcup holders for SphereBot / Completely Printable Eggbot

description.text:
This is my updated version of the semi-completely printable spherebot, aptly named "nearly completely printable spherebot" drawn using google sketchup   
02/28/2014 - uploaded an additional pen mount with a longer stepper arm and longer pen arm with 2 pen rings that are slightly smaller in diameter

Bill of material:
  • 2 stepper motors
  • 1 small servo
  • 1 bread board
  • 1 arduino
  • 2 pololu stepper motors
  • 1 power supply
  • 1 3d printer
  • 1 bearing (got mine off an old skateboard)
  • lots of abs (or material of your choice)
  • 6 M3 bolts
  • 2 M3 nuts
  • 2 nerf gun darts (I like the ones that are orange with the blue tip)
  • 1 super glue to glue the nerf dart tips
  • 1 (or more) sharpie ultra fine tip markers
  • 1 small rubber band
  • jumper wires for wiring breadboard
  • cheap plastic eggs for practice
    • Instructions: (Designed and printed on my lulzbot prusa (www.lulzbot.com ... stroll on over and check out their new TAZ machine ... what I wouldn't give to have one of those beauties sitting in my crazy room) which means if your print bed is about 200 x 200 you should be able to print one of these for yourself. The whole point of me designing this is so I could print all the parts needed for a spherebot. Well, I didn't quite get the "complete" part of "completely printable spherebot" so this one is named "nearly completely printable spherebot" and not to be confused with my previous spherebot "semi-completely printable spherebot" posted over at thingiverse. Given that I'm not likely to come up with a functional printable stepper motor and arduino, I'm thinking this is as "completely" printable as I'm going to get. Last year I published a "semi-completely printable spherebot" on thingiverse (thing: 18994). After giving it some thought (which my mother-in-law claims is as rare as a unicorn with a rainbow saddle) I've redesigned the frame and the cup holders and the pen holder so this doesn't look anything like my previous spherebot, but it is closer to being "fully" printable in that all you have to provide is the steppers, arduino, breadboard, rubber band, M3 nuts and bolts, pololu's etc ... all the STL files have been run thru the netfabb software because, as I've come to expect and probably comes as no surprise to anyone who has seen my work, I'm not an engineer and so all my sketchup work is shady at best. you may also want to download mike_linus' Nut Job nut and bolt scad file from thingiverse (thing: 193647) in case you need to alter the spherebot_bolt84.stl and spherebot_nut9x20.stl that I am including. altho Mike did graciously give permission for me to include these files in this upload, so you will get these files when you download my other files. However, it's worth a trip over to thingiverse to see Mike's original posting of this project and a few of his other great designs. Mike also mentioned that his work is a derivative of aubenc's work (thing: 8796) so certainly want to give aubenc credit for his good work too all the gcode and skp's are uploaded so you should be able to print one for yourself or modify to suit your taste. print all the parts. some parts will need to be sanded/filed/smoothed in order to fit or slide but rather than mention all those details, I'll just leave it for you to figure out what needs what based on your printer. I did include a small tray that allows you to lean the arduino and the bread board against the frame, thus adding some sort of order to the whole thing. I'm trying to figure out a better system for the sphere holder cups as I can't seem to keep an egg centered on the axis. If you have any ideas, i would appreciate some input on this or perhaps you could design it and do a remix. These are the stl file names with a description for each: nearly_complete_spherebot.tar.gz - all the files you need in one tidy tar'd gzip'd file. spherebot_pen_mount-d.stl - (red parts in the picture) these are the parts that attach to the stepper and the servo which controls the drawing pen. There are 5 parts in this print. The longest part attaches to the shaft of the stepper. The servo attaches to the rectangle hole. The circular parts hold the pen (you may need some tape as the shaft is slightly bigger than the pen size. There are 2 of these pen holders so you can do a quick change of pen colors if you like. The last 2 parts are the horizontal arm which olds the pen holder shafts and attaches to the arm which has the servo. also note there is a "key" that attaches with super glue to the horizontal arm and should slide freely in the vertical arm. The second rubber band is wrapped around the vertical and horizontal arms such that it provides downward pull for the pen. The rubber band is not in the picture, but if you look at one of the completely assembled pics, you'll see how I used it spherebot_cup_motor.stl - (green part in pic) bolts on to the shaft of the second stepper motor that rotates the sphere. blue tip of the nerf dart glues onto this part. There is a few MM of room on the shaft so you can move it in or out as needed. spherebot_bolt84.stl - (green part in pic) this works with the spherebot_nut9x20.stl. slide the bolt through the 2 retainer clips (blue parts in pic) and then attach the nut. My experience "post-publish" indicates that the unthreaded portion of this bolt probably needs to be a a little bit longer spherebot_nut9x20.stl - (green part in pic) attaches to the bolt after it's threaded thru the retainer clips (blue parts in pic). blue tip of nerf dart attaches to one side of this nut. The bolt/nut is used so you have some MM of room for adjustment. spherebot_retainer_plates.stl - (blue parts in pic) attaches to the side of the frame opposite the stepper motor. used to restrict wobble movement of the bolt/nut combination. They also help hold the skateboard bearing in place. I don't know that you need the bearing ... but I figure I have to store it some place and this is just as good as any. The round button looking part is designed to have the rubber band put through the tunnel. Each end of the rubber band is then attached the outer retainer plate such that the button acts as a spring, pushing the bolt towards the intersection of the 2 stepper motor axis. spherebot_frame.stl - (yellow parts in pic) this is the new design for the spherebot. Notice there are 6 vertical holes in the frame. There is no magic for these holes. They were put in to cut down on the amount of plastic used and to help prevent the layers from doing that "boating" effect. IE, while printing, the layers begin to separate and kinda curl up. Since incorporating them in the design, it occurred to me I may need to use them to elevate the frame off the table in case I were to draw on something like an ornament or something bigger than an egg....but that's something I'll have to figure out later. spherebot_frame_untested - this file is a frame which I have yet to print. Based on the one in the pics but with more surface holes. I'm still trying to figure out a way to keep the horizontal layers from separating during print and this is one shot at doing that. HOWEVER, this frame has a couple of changes that should make it a better print overall. For one, the slots for the vertical pen arm are closer to fitting the vertical arm and the balance plates under the stepper motors are detached from the frame which should help the print fit on smaller plates. spherebot_Nut_Job.scad - this is not my work. It belongs to the thingiverse user named mike_linus. It's an easy to use openscad file for generating nuts and bolts. spherebot_bolt84.scad - this is not my work. It's a derivative of spherebot_Nut_Job.scad for generating the bolt that fits the spherebot. spherebot_nut9x20.scad - this is not my work. it's a derivative of spherebot_Nut_Job.scad for generating the nut that fits the spherebot spherebot_all.stl - this file has all the relevant STL files on one Slic3r board so in theory you could print all the parts in one shot. But I am warning you, I did not use this STL to print the parts in the pictures so I make no warranty, express or implied, as to the suitability or fitness for print of this file.

comments.text: I haven't tried this design, but I have built a(n) spherebot/eggobt.  Yes, the pen axis does need to move up and down to allow for the change from spherical to egg shaped.
comments.author: Tommy714

comments.text: Unfortunately this can never work with a non spherical object due to the pen arm rotation axis intersecting the object's rotational axis. In order to best fit non spherical shapes, the pen arm needs to be able to move below (or even above) the object's axis....

title: Harbor Freight (HF) Motorcycle Tire changer hooks

description.text:
These are solid and designed for the HF tire changer motorcycle adapter without its own hooks but with the flush back plate [ http://www.harborfreight.com/media/catalog/product/cache/1/image/9df78eab33525d08d6e5fb8d27136e95/i/m/image_23490.jpg ]. Nylon or ABS recommended, and ABS may need to up the infill percentage.

v2 is shelled in the lower area and solid at the top where the rim hook actually is. It also has more material on top, shallower rim notches, and bigger fillets on bottom to ease hammering the insert into place. The downside is I haven't tested V2...yet

If you would like these re-licensed in a commercially usable way, drop me a line. Otherwise it is expected per GPL that any design changes or integration point must be shared.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

50%

Notes:

STL file designed so honeycomb would face the direction of clamping for maximum compression strength against the infill structure. If you don't print on the X-Y plane, the objects in the STL file may need to be adjusted. My print was done using 1.75mm ABS with a 95C heated bed.

Includes all 3 hooks in this one file.

I do have the FreeCAD parametric design file. I am not posting it because I don't want HF (or it's Chinese suppliers) to use it without permission

Fixing something sold as broken in about an hour

Took some measurements, put it in FreeCAD, and then in slic3r. Not very hard.

You can set them with a deadblow hammer and not need to drill holes because they are very tight. the original had problems with the hooks cracking if you hammered them away from the solid section, so be careful. The also will be very hard to remove mechanically with machining them.

This the second prototype in a series of work exploring Candy Dispensers as building materials for sculptural forms and interventions. In this piece I am curious as to whether the Dispenser Stems could be arranged to produce edges and vertices similar to those found in simple platonic solids that are at the core of most 3D modeling programs. My goal is to produce the Spheres in conjunction with Pyramids, and Cubes to produce larger sculptural objects and decorative interiors. (right now it's a bit egg shaped - hence the work in progress status - i think i need to adjust some angles, or add some more stems - hopefully will have time to address this soon-ish). Exhibited so far at Open Source Gallery in Brooklyn and Firecat Projects in Chicago. Available from Fuse-Works: http://www.fuse-works.com/Tom%20Burtonwood-p-00317-i-Detail# Photo courtesy of Fuse-Works.

author: richardtracy

print_settings.Notes:: perfect

description.text:
UPDATED 27-AUG-2017.

After playing around with the end screw a bit I discovered that no matter what material I used (ABS or Nylon), the stress on the part is just too much for it and it eventually breaks. So, I decided to re-use the threaded hex rod portion from the original Qidi Tech 1 spools instead. If you feel brave and want to use all 3D printed parts, just use the parts "End Screw" and "Mounting Screw". If you want to go for max strength instead by reusing the rod, print "Adapter" instead of "End Screw".

UPDATED 26-AUG-2017.

After getting the bearings in for the spool I discovered I had to fine tune not only the mounting screw but also the end cap screw. The mounting screw now has a hex key hole through it to ease installation as well as a built-in washer-spacer. The end screw from the original has been modified to not only include a hex key hole as well but also with the built-in washer too.

The Perfect Qidi/Flashforge Spool Holder (www.thingiverse.com/thing:1795763) really is a great replacement for the lousy stock spool holders on the QIDI TECH 1, but for my printer there was no way to mount the spools.

I reworked the double-ended screw (the one that's closest to the printer) so one side is smaller and is now able to screw into the printer just like the stock holders.

There is a "catch" with this part though. Although I ordered bearings I haven't received them yet, so I haven't been able to test it fully assembled when using bearings. As it is you actually can use the spool holder without bearings though, and with this part it fits the QT1 perfectly.

If you decide to make the spools and this part and not use bearings, you only have to print out this part (obviously), and everything from the other download except the washers, the washer/nut, and the large nut piece. When I eventually get the bearings in I'll check and see what modifications I need to do to this part to make it all work and I'll publish a new adapter piece.

Printer:

Qidi Tech 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.40 nozzle/0.2 layer height

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used ABS at 100% infill, 4 solid top layers, 4 solid bottom layers, and 4 perimeter shells. You can probably get away with less but considering this part has to handle all the stress of the spool, I made it as sturdy as possible. If you have it, Nylon filament would be perfect for the mounting screw portion since it's a part that sees a lot of stress.

title: Simple Electric longboard remote - Arduino controlled

description.text:
This is my attempt to make a simple and reliable remote for electric skateboards. The main electronics are an Arduino Nano, a Hall Effect sensor, and an nRF24 radio module. You can find a full parts list here: https://goo.gl/EXNYyZ

The software, documentation and schematics can be found on my github page: https://github.com/SolidGeek/nRF24-Esk8-Remote

I recommend printing the bottom and top shell top-down, so you don't need any supports - and gets a nice finish if you are printing on glass.

Hope you enjoy!

Printer:

Afinibot A31 (CR-10)

Infill:

50

print_settings.Notes:: Print flat on the base at a 45 degree angle to fit on the A8 platform.  You need 2 of them!

description.text:
The long unsupported length of threaded rods in the middle of my A8 bothered me. I made this simple brace to finish out the bottom of the printer and add some rigidity to the threaded rods. It has a hex pattern to match front/rear braces found on here by other users. This probably doesn't do much, but it looks cool and may lend some extra stiffness to the Y axis. Note that it does not touch whatever surface your printer sits on; it is intended to clamp to the Anet frame via the nuts and support the threaded rods.

My printer is called "Archimedes", hence the text. The STL I uploaded does not have this text.

The brace is split in half so each half will fit on the A8 build platform at a 45 degree angle. Print the 2 halves one at a time, flat on their bottom with no supports and 30% hex infill.

Install as pictured and snug the nuts up pretty good.

I used Solidworks for the design and Simplify3D to slice.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.15

Infill:

30% Hex

Notes:

Print flat on the base at a 45 degree angle to fit on the A8 platform. You need 2 of them!
